repnme.cdata!:
Sudan - Capacity Building Institutional and
            Human Resource Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Capacity Building
            Institutional and Human Resource Development Project for
            Sudan were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was high; Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory; and grantee
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: there are a number of lessons to be learnt
            from this project which is specific to the project itself.
            These are set out below. Project outputs should not be
            linked to the outputs of other projects since non completion
            or delay in the linked projects can adversely affect project
            outputs. This is particularly true in fragile environments
            where there is a frequent change in the priorities of
            government, the administrative processes are not
            institutionalized and the regulatory framework is unclear.
            'high tech' interventions in fragile states such
            as Information and Communication Technology (ICT) need to
            have a sustained program of support spanning at least five
            to seven years with adequate 'contracting in' of
            capacity provided for in the project itself. Qualified human
            resources to support the intervention are not easily
            attracted to work in the public sector even if they are
            available. The project relied on the confidence of the
            government that they would be in a position to recruit and
            appoint qualified staff to manage the interstate
            telecommunication links, the Video Conferencing
            infrastructure and the Government of Southern Sudan (GoSS)
            email. Significant thought needs to be given to engagements
            which require 'counterpart' funding of running
            costs over the short to medium term. A number of
            interventions have suffered due to basic running costs,
            intended to be met by government not eventually being
            provided for in budget disbursements. Whilst it might be
            feasible to solicit covenants from governments relating to
            these at the outset of the project, it is clear that in a
            fragile environment it is difficult to make these binding.
            Project interventions and resultant outputs and outcomes
            must be imbedded in policy documents, legislation or
            regulations of the recipient if they are to be implemented
            in a short project period of three years.

repnme.cdata!:
Sudan - Institutional and Human Development
            in South Sudan Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Institutional and
            Human Development in South Sudan Project is to provide the
            foundation for effective, efficient and transparent
            functioning of the Government of Southern Sudan (GoSS) by:
            1) strengthening the capacity of key ministries, 2)
            improving the management of information within government
            and, 3) enhancing the governments capacity for internal and
            external communications; and to increase access to labour
            market, welfare and vocational training services by
            developing the governments capacity for regulating the
            labour market and designing and implementing labour market
            and vocational training programs. The project expenditure
            increased to 86 percent by end of October 2010. Around 98
            percent of the project amount is committed and 80 percent of
            the project activities have been completed. The no cost
            extension is necessary to ensure that one sub component from
            the rehabilitation of the Juba Vocational Training Centers
            (VTC) and the incomplete sub components related to the
            Ministry of postal and telecommunication services can be completed.

            Development in South Sudan Project : restructuring (Vol. 2)
